review.title: Clustering and Relational Ambiguity: from Text Data to Natural Data
review.abstract: Text data is often seen as "take-away" materials with little noise and easy to process information. Main questions are how to get data and transform them into a good document format. But data can be sensitive to noise oftenly called ambiguities. Ambiguities are aware from a long time, mainly because polysemy is obvious in language and context is required to remove uncertainty. I claim in this paper that syntactic context is not suffisant to improve interpretation. In this paper I try to explain that firstly noise can come from natural data themselves, even involving high technology, secondly texts, seen as verified but meaningless, can spoil content of a corpus; it may lead to contradictions and background noise.

metadata.title: Clustering and Relational Ambiguity: from Text Data to Natural Data

sections.text: Text data is often considered to be "take-away" materials with low noise and easy-to-process information, but data can be sensitive to noise, which is often referred to as ambiguities. Ambiguities have long been known, mainly because polysemy in language and context is obvious to eliminate uncertainty. I argue in this paper that syntactic context is not enough to improve interpretation. In this paper, I try to explain that, first, noise can come from natural data itself, even involving high technology; second, texts that are considered verified but meaningless can corrode the contents of a corpus; it can lead to contradictions and background noise. Keyword paradox; contradiction; ambiguity; semantic relationship; domain; information extraction; corpus.

sections.heading: INTRODUCTION
sections.text: In this sense, it is also possible to test the validity or consistency of a relationship. Let's emphasize the validity of a relationship that is nothing other than intolerance of death.

sections.heading: I RELATIONAL AMBIGUITY IN DATA
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 1.1 Antinomy and paradox in mathematics
sections.text: In philosophy and logic, the paradox has been ascribed to Greek rhetoric during the VII century before JC. The first paradox was the lyer of epimenids. It states that "a man said he was lying. What he said was true or false?" In another way, we let epimenids say: "All Cretans are lyers." This was considered a paradox by ancient philosophers. By the way: Either epimenids tell the truth, then he lies (because he is a Cretan), so his statement is false (because all Cretans lie). Either, on the contrary, epimenids lie by saying that, then their statement is false: there is at least one Crete who tells the truth, which is not contradictory, because it is the solution of the paradox. In modern mathematics, the logic Russel is the following paradox formulated by this question: "the class of all classes, which are not an element of itself, is an element of itself."

sections.heading: 1.2 Antinomy in linguistics
sections.text: Most of them are verbs and adjectives such as: move back / forward, start / stop, rise / decrease, black / white, fast / slow, wet / dry. We can also find what is called quasi-antagonyms, such as bonus / terrible.

sections.heading: 1.3 Relational ambiguity in a specialized domain
sections.text: If we focus on a specialized discourse, the opposition might take on a different form. [Reinitz et al., 1998] In molecular biology, fly species have been studied and demonstrated an ambiguity in the role of the SmaI-BglI protein to produce strip 6 in the fly's body. [Howard et al., 1990] "Further deletion analyses of this region (especially ET44, 30 and 31) provide clear evidence that a 600 bp region of DNA (from positions -8.4 to -9.0; ET31) contains all elements necessary and sufficient for a relatively normal reaction of strip 6 (Fig. 3B). However, we point out that this reaction appears to be slightly posterior to the position of the endogenous strip c-6."

sections.heading: 1.4 Comparison of real and artificial corpora
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before.

sections.heading: 1.5 Discussion
sections.text: Some sciences try to learn close links between components, we can cite chemistry and sociology. Some other sciences try to get to know more global structures such as economics and astrophysics. Computational linguistics and lexical statistics are areas that are able to get an overview of a whole range of relationships and focus on specific relationships. In this chapter we try to show some results for an overall overview of closed relationships in the same short documents, which are highlighted by some elements that have to do with specific argumentative relationships. First, we try to explain how contradictions in texts can explicitly occur as specific relationships. Second, two companies have been studied to extract global information, which have common characteristics such as: short document size, technical domain, English language, natural distribution of lexical objects, body size. Nevertheless, a corpus is a domain that is studied by many people as a scientifically active area (i.e. biodiversity), which other "false documents" are written by people as the "real documents."

sections.heading: 2.1 Visual ambiguities
sections.text: Medicine [Fang et al, 2004] [Kirkpatrick et al, 2006] [Pagenstert et al, 2006] [Pagenstert et al, 2008] [Brusseau et al, 1999] [Lazyuk et al, 1996] [Blinov & Mazurov, 2011] [Canafoglia et al, 2006] [Palmu & Syrjenen, 2005] [Kazmierczak et al, 2008] [Perea et al, 2007] Psychology [Peterson et al, 1992] [Grossmann et al, 2005] [Schirillo et al, 2006] [Maltby et al, 2008] [Cashera et al, 2007] [Robertson et al, 2000] [Rakoczi andPohl, 2012] [Kaveiwabata, 1993] [Kim et al, 2003] [Drogemuller, 2009] [Shirillo and Shevell, 1997] [Maltby et al, 2008] [Cashera et al, 2008] [Brushera et al al, 2003, Brushera et al, 2003 Neveil al al, 2003 2003, 2009 Neveischel al, 2004 [Mcveiences et al, 2003] [1993] [Drogemuller et al, 2012] [Kim et al, 2012] [Rakzi] [Kim et al, 2012]

sections.heading: Medical Observation
sections.text: The other major obstacle is the ambiguous interpretation of therapeutic effects, especially when the pre-treatment phase is the delayed relaxation pattern normally observed in diabetics [Fang et al, 2004]. In schizophrenia, dysphoria or psychotic symptoms should improve simultaneously while negative symptoms improve, it is not clear whether there has been a direct effect on negative symptoms [Kirkpatrick et al, 2006]. Clinical studies with different signs and functional tests are used for sometimes insufficient quantification and interpretation problems [Pagenstert and Bachman, 2008]. Analysis of multiexponential defects often leads to hard interpretation confirming the limited diagnostic value of relaxation times [Perea et al, 2007]. The presence of several positive peaks before and after average glucose results led to an ambiguous interpretation of the coupling between EEG transients and EMG potentials [Cana et al, 2006].

sections.heading: Psychology drawing
sections.text: In fact, most people living in the US are able to understand themselves and what they are doing.

sections.heading: Physical systems
sections.text: A number of classification models of the flow regime have been reported in the literature on the basis of subjective and variable visual observations, such as the Mandhane flow regime map [Cai et al, 1994]. In astrophysical images, values of parameters can lead to misunderstandings [McIntosh et al, 2004]. Radar images offer an advantage for observing Earth change regardless of weather conditions, but detecting some features such as roads is more difficult [Chibani et al, 2003]. In coronary applications, the position of the catheter changes due to the curved nature of the arteries. This gives images that do not correspond to the expected cross-section of the stent and lead to ambiguous interpretation by physicians [Brusseau et al, 1999]. [Honnicke et al, 2005] report that the overlapping of details resulting from these three main contrast sequences can lead to an ambiguous interpretation of the image, although mathematical image processing has improved as if the dispersion was a problem to solve.

sections.heading: Biological systems
sections.text: As a result of ambiguous morphological similarities, many species have been shifted between genera or even families since the earliest exhaustive classifications of liverworms [Hentschel et al, 2007]. According to [Carette and Ferguson, 1992], both programmed cell death and, in particular, the epithelial-mesenchymal transformation theory of suture degeneration are based on the potentially ambiguous interpretation of a dynamic event from a series of static images. In phylogenetics, [Yu et al, 2010] pointed to an ambiguous interpretation of the conclusions for the entire cladogram. [Palomares-Ruis et al, 2010] Representatives of phylogenetic relationships within plant-parasitic nematodes such as longi-doridae pointed out, especially in cases where morphological characters can lead to ambiguous interpretations of signal resources. [Gantchev et al, 1992] Supporters of spin-labelling techniques remind us that biological interpretation of the membrane is inherently difficult, but the dynamical one.

sections.heading: 2.2 Measure ambiguities
sections.text: Physics [Shakal & Bernreuter, 1980] [Courteau et al, 2007] [McIntosh et al, 2004] [Garland et al, 2001] [Zhang et al, 2007] [Kwon and Kubicki, 2004] [Yoshida et al, 2008] [Zhang et al, 1989] [Standish, 1993] [Daragan and Mayo, 1995] Biology [Gianola et al, 2006] [Mollet et al, 1997] [Noth and Benecke, 2005] [Peano et al, 2005] [Iron Smoke et al, 1989] [Kloczkowski et al, 2002] [Kompalic-Cristo et al, 2004] [Battles et al, 1995] [Ounis et al, 2001] [Moskovets et al, 2003] Anthropology [Iron Smoke et al, 1989] [Kloczkowski et al, 2002] [Kompalic-Cristo et al, 1993] [Battles et al, 1993] [Ounis et al, 2001] [Won and Min, 2010] [Moskovets et al, 2003] Anthropology [Iron Smoke et al, 1989] [Kloczkowski et al, 2002] [Kloczkowski et al, 2002] [Kompalic-Cristo et al, 2004] [Kompalic-Cristo et al, 2004] [Battles et al al, 1993] [Ounis et al, 1993] [Ounis et al, 2001] [Won and Min, 2001 2001] Mcguildish et al, 2001 2001 [Anthropology [Wassenberg], 2001, 2001]

sections.heading: Physical measure
sections.text: The distance dependence of ground motion relations derived from obvious data is very sensitive to the ambiguous interpretation of the distance when the station is a source dimension or less from the disturbance. Therefore, the choice of method for measuring the distance can have dramatic effects on the resulting ground motion curves [Shakal et Bernreuter, 1980]. For the galaxy NGC 4278, as reported in P05, Vc (H I) = 326 ± 40, while Vc (model) = 416 ± 13 result in a rather interpretation problem of Vc [Courteau et al, 2007]. Depending on the experimental system, some effects between liquid / metal interfaces can significantly modify the shape of the current transients and lead to an incorrect understanding of experimental data [Garland et al, 2001].

sections.heading: Chemical measure
sections.text: Without detailed knowledge of the composition of the reaction products, coulometric reduction can lead to different explanations [Lenglet et al, 1995]. Mössbauer spectra at room temperature supplemented by powder X-ray diffraction analysis of relatively ferrous soil samples and their particle size fractions are, however, compared to demonstrate the ambiguous interpretation of iron oxides in mineralogy [Pizarro et al, 2000]. Many hypotheses have been further developed to take into account the absence of organs and the possible chemicals and reactions responsible for the ambiguous biological experiments, although they are reliable, each of the electrochemical techniques on its own [Kounaves et al, 2003].

sections.heading: Biological measure
sections.text: The use of multiple molecular markers as tools in genetic selection programs can be corrupted by collinearity [Gianola et al, 2006] Some DNA sequences, such as the 16S rRNA sequencing, may occur in species that harbor multiple copies of the 16S rRNA gene, as shown between the various operations in E.coli [Mollet et al, 1997].The importance of unambiguous annotations from microarray experiments.The different probes and gene IDs that correspond to the two annotations create uncertainties [Noth and Benecke, 2005].PCR methods can sometimes be controversial, and post-PCR control is often indispensable to confirm a sequence identity in relation to specific targets [Peano et al, 2005].

sections.heading: Anthropological measure
sections.text: Different values (class correlation or internal consistency) between the interviewees arise in part from different interpretations of the article and / or the explanation [Wassenberg et al, 2003]. The study of social and professional contexts, behaviors of flirting did not seem to be limited to flirting [Keyton and Rhodes, 1997], not least because of the difficulty of defining ecological boundaries in the face of a knowledge base that is usually imperfect and prone to ambiguous interpretation [Crean and Wisher, 2000]. Analysis of the main elements of both regulations confirms that there is an ambiguous interpretation of the so-called Preservation Zone (Suelo de Conservacion), which represents a territory subject to conservation, its ecological value in terms of climate regulation, water enrichment, forest communities, agricultural cultivation and agricultural use. This situation favors illegal land use programs [Aguilar, 2008].

sections.heading: Psychological measure
sections.text: The first conception of machine design focused on epistemic fidelity (consistency between the physical representation of some phenomena and the mental representation of this phenomenon by the expert), but since the representation of physical and mental representations is an inherently ambiguous process of interpretation, users did not read representations as the experts did [Dillenbourg, 1996]. [Allegro, 1990] examined linguistic form to understand therapeutic effects. He used inkblots as a test when confronted with interpretation problems. [Charash and McKay, 2009] took a test with sixty participants in several groups, were identified and engaged with a masked emotional impact test, implicit memory task and ambiguous interpretation task. Individuals with increased contingent anxiety would exhibit distortions of attention or memory. Behaviors may be sources of confusion [Charlton, 2000] the interpretation of a given category would be subject to questions related to soccer and dispositions, if they were subjected to dispositions.

sections.heading: Geological measure
sections.text: A palaeomagnetic test of the Patagonian oroclins shows an ambiguous interpretation of the declension anomaly without palaeohorizontal control [Rapalini, 2007]. A correlated 2D cross-section can lead to an ambiguous interpretation, which can be an archaeological body [ElQady et al, 1999]. [Liu and Liu, 2008] consider 2-D seismic data and a low signal-to-noise ratio, which leads to an ambiguous interpretation. [Poudjom Djomani et al, 2003] explain that the extent of the terrans depends on the ambiguous interpretation of magnetic anomalies. For example, the Birekt terrane is fully detected on geophysical bases, as the foundation is overlaid by up to 10 km of Riphean Schnyll Schnyll, which are being investigated in the time by tuberyl, where for example pairs are compared [Klose, 2006].

sections.heading: Medical measure
sections.text: The evaluation of the markers was not treated as a universally accepted criterion that can occasionally lead to uncertainty due to variations in these parameters [Casas Pina, 1999]. Observations from Interrater Experiment 2 were used to adapt and improve the tool, and few criteria were found to contribute to the heterogeneity of the Rater results by causing misunderstandings [Schneider et al, 2009]. [Venturin et al, 2004] used published reports and recruited patients to build a common data structure in which the information is tabulated. For each patient, we added each new clinical sign that had not previously been recorded, thus obtaining a relational database of 103 fields. The presence of a specific character was attributed only when explicitly reported and formalized in a binary manner (i.e., present or non-existent).

sections.heading: Economical measure
sections.text: Comparisons such as cost-income ratios cannot be correlated with most other metrics, which suggests that it is an unreliable indicator of competition and inefficiency as a result of its ambiguous interpretation [Ozdincer and Ozyildirim, 2011].The proportion of sample loans backed by collateral is a characteristic for comparing borrowers across countries.The interpretation of collateral as a risk variable is particularly ambiguous [Smith, 2003].[ Starczak and Jakubiec, 2003] claim that some companies appreciate the importance of unambiguous documentation and define the details of measurement strategy, but the ambiguous interpretation of design requirements still exists too often in practice. In one test, subjects were asked about their price-quality beliefs for twenty-eight product categories. However, after the preliminary test, positions for threshold and price variables were referenced due to ambiguous interpretation by subjects [Smith and 1999].

sections.heading: Computation
sections.text: Sometimes statistical assumptions are rarely fulfilled, the null hypotheses tests provide ambiguous results depending on the dispersion of the data [Tedeschi, 2006]. Niehaus and Terry (1993) find the regression coefficients of delayed excess variables on premiums for one and two periods. Sometimes data (tuples in databases) need to be compared with other tuples to clarify their meanings [Jukic and Vrbsky, 1997] [Lucas et al, 2009]. Situation recognition for Vehicular Traffic Scenarios, dealing with temporal contexts leads to imprecise interpretations [Meyer-Delius, 2009]. [Shapiro et al, 1993] points out that IDEF (Icam DEFinition for Function Modeling) can be irrelevant. Arrows can connect by allowing the interpretation of fan-in or merging.

sections.heading: Statistics
sections.text: The validity of the differences confuses the effects of their component measurements, and the failure to explain variance beyond their component measurements also allows for less precise interpretation [Edwards, 1994]. Confusion in endogenous circuit model specifications can therefore cause problems of interpretation [Huang et al, 1991]. Inspection of the vibration response of a beam with an edge that does not propagate leads to uncertainty. If the injury is small, this is revealed by numerical applications that do not seem to provide information about the location of the crack [Cacciola, 2003]. [Thompson and Geyer, 2007] emphasize that conventional p-values have ambiguous interpretation unless they are extreme. Two important risk areas with all stochastic estimation processes are identified as unreliability of the estimates, and ambiguous interpretation [Pons, 2006].

sections.heading: 2.4 Discussion
sections.text: In this chapter, we follow the idea of the first chapter, where ambiguity and confusion are contained in data. Many sciences, information and data can lead an expert in a confusing position to offer a precise interpretation. We cited for each science a pool of studies that is only representative but not exhaustive of problems that arise. In case of ambiguity in texts, the two effects of misinterpretation and erroneous results can play an important role.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we present two sources of contradictions that occur in textual data: the first is purely syntactical in nature and refers to the writer's intention in his article; the second is related factual data derived from experiments and leading to an elementary basis of interpretation; the purpose of the essay influences the way an article is written; and if the writer's intention is ethically related to scientific truth needs, ambiguity is based only on difficulties in obtaining unambiguous factual data from experiments caused by noise or the absence of current cataegories to facilitate interpretation. If a writer's intention is motivated by his career and reputation enhancement, data does not play a central role, but only a writer's rethoric discourse that leads to inappropriate relationships but is explained in the same way as real facts. In this study, we have tried to identify the source of uncertainty in order to interpret omissions in data.

metadata.abstractText: Text data is often seen as “take-away” materials with little noise and easy to process information. Main questions are how to get data and transform them into a good document format. But data can be sensitive to noise oftenly called ambiguities. Ambiguities are aware from a long time, mainly because polysemy is obvious in language and context is required to remove uncertainty. I claim in this paper that syntactic context is not suffisant to improve interpretation. In this paper I try to explain that firstly noise can come from natural data themselves, even involving high technology, secondly texts, seen as verified but meaningless, can spoil content of a corpus; it may lead to contradictions and background noise. keywords paradox ; contradiction ; ambiguity ; semantic relationship ; domain ; information extraction ; corpus INTRODUCTION Human cognition call a diversity of concepts such as memory and brain anatomy, inference and reasoning, motivation, time and space, classification and clustering. Inference tries to identify good relations or properties associated to an object. In this sense it is also possible to test validity or consistency of a relation. Let be the proposition P = “a cat is a stone” is false or contradictory because a stone is not a living organism, though a cat is a living organism. P can be called paradoxal or contradictory. Sometimes society lives with contradictions such as tolerance to lots of death on roads or in wars but intolerance for death with diseases. In this paper we more specifically focuse on sources of potential contradictions which could spoil computation of information extraction. Formal semantics is attached to validate relations between a set of objects. Our focuse is not only to study issues is managing complexity of a logical proposition and how to compute if it true or false but given a text consisting of a set of sentences how to extract relations and see how they be asserted as non contradictory regards others relations extracted in others texts. So texts are the primary material of discussion. Chapter 1 presents relational ambiguities we can find in texts. We start to present a typology of logical relations. Given a type of relations, we explain how to extract such relations with markers in texts. But markers are not sufficient to detect a contradiction. A specialized language such as molecular corpus gives example of ambiguous relations (contradictory) that can not be detected with markers. Hence we show that global overview of words collocations in a corpuscan give a good signal about the structure. In our “publish or publish” new era of research and development system, production of literature is high but a non-negligible percent of papers becomes false over time. It is possible to compile from Pubmed website 4,800 papers honestly accepted but hence officially retracted. Such amount of information is original to make a corpus of real texts, written with intentional to propose arguments and content to readers, in a real natural language, but knowing that the content has been invalidated ex-post by readers. To build a random text is quite easy but the grammar and arguments will not be normalized by how argumentation is made usually by “normal writers and experts”, or natural language will not confirm standard used of official grammars and
